item.title: How to handle Dates and Times with lubridate
item.description: This is comming soon … Stick around.

item.title: About
item.description: Welcome to R Data Science 101 About me My name Juan Lorenzo Arellano and I have extensive experience with technology, data bases, virtualization, storage and mission critical services. Nevertheless, I am kind of new in the Data Science domain but I got captivated by its essence and power. I started learning R in 2019 and after the initial hurdles of learning anything for first time, I very rapidly managed to analyze technical datasets that had financial implications at work, that allowed me to get powerful insights we didn’t get before with traditional methods and tools like Excel.

item.title: How to add and subtract Dates and Times in R
item.description: Introduction Following the R recipe How to deal with Date and Time in R where we reviewed the base R capabilities to deal with dates and times, we continue exploring how to add and subtract dates and times, also in base R. I plan to cover lubridate and clock packages in the future. Addition of a scalar to a date It’s very common that we need to calculate an end date for a process or service knowing only the starting date and the duration.

item.title: How to deal with Dates and Times in R
item.description: Introduction A common need that exists in most of the programming languages is parsing strings into dates and converting dates into strings. Mastering this process is of vital importance for data analysts/data scientist because we get data from many different sources and countries where format changes, and for dates this is typically a headache. For instance, “31st of January of 2021” can be written as: 01/31/21: US format January the 31, 2021: US format 31/01/21: typically European format 31.
